data.text:
LEAD: OF ALL the roles Cliff Robertson has played in a stage, film and television career that began on Broadway in 1953, he estimates there have been 40 major ones, including his portrayal of ''Charly'' in that Academy Award-winning movie of 1968.

OF ALL the roles Cliff Robertson has played in a stage, film and television career that began on Broadway in 1953, he estimates there have been 40 major ones, including his portrayal of ''Charly'' in that Academy Award-winning movie of 1968.

But none, he says, has ever hit quite as close to home as the part he is re-creating at the John Drew Theater in East Hampton.

For two weeks, starting Tuesday, Mr. Robertson again will be Andrew Makepeace Ladd 3d in ''Love Letters,'' A. R. Gurney's acclaimed two-character play that takes a couple, through a lifetime of correspondence, from childhood to middle age.

And being Andrew, Mr. Robertson said in an interview, is practically like being Cliff Robertson.

A Personal Identification

''I really identify with him,'' said the actor, who played the staid, almost priggish character in the production's final week on Broadway last January. ''In fact, I've never done anything on stage, in a movie or on TV that I can personally identify with the same way,''
